Appeal under Arts. 132  1  and 134  1  c  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated I3th October, 1950, of the High Court
It appears that the petition was argued by both the sides as it was one made under article 926 of the Constitution.

This appeal has been preferred by the State of Bihar against the judgment of a Special Bench of the High Court of Judicature at Patna allowing the application of the respondent under section 23 of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers Act, XXIII of 1931.

holdings.text: Section 4(1)(a) of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act is constitutional as it imposes restrictions solely directed against undermining the security of the State and falls within Article 19(2).

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that speeches or expressions on the part of an individual which incite to or encourage the commission of violent crimes, such as murder, cannot but be matters which would undermine the security of the State and come within the ambit of a law sanctioned by article. 19 2 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Romesh Thapar and Brij Bhushan (broader public order restrictions) from specific incitement to violence/murder affecting State security; wide interpretation of Art.19(2); confirmed by retrospective First Amendment.

holdings.text: The restrictions imposed by section 4(1)(a) are within Article 19(2) even prior to amendment, as Romesh Thapar does not compel invalidity.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arose in Romesh Thapars case 1 was whether the impugned Act Madras Maintenance Public Order Act, XXIII of 1949 in so far as it purported by section 9 1-A

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 9(1-A) Madras Act broader (public safety/order) unlike narrow incitement to violence in s.4(1)(a); no direct bearing of precedents on validity.

holdings.text: Amendment to Article 19(2) by Constitution First Amendment Act is not repugnant to Article 20.

anchor.surface_text: Basant Chander Ghosh contended that the amendment made in article 19 2 of the Constitution with retrospective operation was repugnant to article 20 of the Constitution

holdings.reasoning_summary: No conviction or retrospective creation of offence; respondent not convicted; Art.20 inapplicable to security demand under existing law.

holdings.text: The pamphlet does not fall within the mischief of section 4(1)(a) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Though, as I have said above, the High Court is in error in the finding that the provisions of section ,4 1 a 1 1950 S.C.R594, of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act are repugnant to the Constitution, its judgment has to be maintained

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document as whole contains abstract slogans, demagogic claptrap, no specific grievance/agitation; no evidence of context/tendency to incite violence in reasonable readers.

holdings.text: To determine if a document falls under section 4(1)(a), consider it as a whole, its general effect on reasonable readers' minds, in context/background, without overemphasizing isolated passages.

anchor.surface_text: In order to determine whether a particular document falls within the ambit section 4 1 , the writing has to be considered as a whole and in a fair and free and liberal spirit, not dwelling too much upon isolated passages

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied to facts: pamphlet's hyperbolic, abstract nature lacks incitement potency absent proven circumstances; distinguishes Badri Narain (specific appeal).

precedents.citation: Romesh Thapar The State of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Romesh Thapar The State of Madras 1 , and Brij Bhushan V. The State of Delhi 2 , found, though with some reluctance, that section 4 1 a of the Act was repugnant to the Constitution and therefore void. Mr. Justice Shearer, however, held that the pamphlet was a seditious libel and that there was numberhing in the two decisions of the Supreme Court referred to above which companypelled the companyrt to hold the provisions of section 4 1 a of the Act to be void.

precedents.case_name: Romesh Thapar v. The State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: restrictions on freedom of speech must be directed solely against undermining the security of the State or overthrowing it to fall within Article 19(2); wider restrictions for public order are invalid
precedents.cited_holding: section 9(1-A) of Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act authorizing restrictions for public safety or maintenance of public order is void

The time is long past when writings of this kind can in numbermal circumstances excite people to companymit crimes of violence or murder or tend to excite any- body to companymit acts of violence. Again the language employed is full of mysticism and I.L.R. 1964 Nag. 865 cannot be easily understood and it creates numberimpression of any kind on any person.

precedents.case_name: Bhagwati Charan Shukla v. Government of C.P. Berar
precedents.cited_proposition: pamphlets using extravagant language, crude emotional appeal, and attempt to ape poets do not excite people to commit crimes of violence in normal circumstances

precedents.citation: Badri Narain v. Chief Secretary, Bihar Govermnent 2

anchor.surface_text: Badri Narain v. Chief Secretary, Bihar Govermnent 2 . The learned Chief Justice therein held that in order to show that cer- tain words fall under section 4 1 a it is number necessary to show that the words tend to incite or to encourage the companymission of a particular offence or offences and that it is sufficient if they tend to incite to or to encourage the companymission of companynizable offences of violence in general. In that case, a poem entitled Labourers, the mainstayof the world began by emphasising that labourers are the mainstay of the present world and then proceeded to describe their unfortunate and pitiful lot. [...] A.I.R. 1941 Pat.132 create a new world order and that will bring happiness to the whole world.

precedents.case_name: Badri Narain v. Chief Secretary, Bihar Government
precedents.cited_proposition: to fall under section 4(1)(a), it is sufficient if words tend to incite or encourage cognizable offences involving violence in general, without specifying particular offence

anchor.surface_text: Harkrishan Singh v. Emperor 1 , the use of such words as appear in this document creates numberimpression on the mind of any reasonable reader. That case dealt with clause d of section 4 1 , but the principle underlying it also applies to the companystruction of writings which are alleged to fall under section 4 1 a . I do number mean to suggest or to lay down as a general propo- sition that some of the words used in the pamphlet in ques- tion in the companytext of any other writing would number fall within the mischief of section 4 1 a . Certain parts of the pamphlet, if read as isolated passages, may have the tendency to excite people to companymit A,I.R, 1946 Lah, 22. crimes of violence but that is number the effect if the pam- phlet is read in its entirety.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that I would dismiss the appeal but in the circumstances would make no order as to costs. The State Government has succeeded in its contention that sec- tion 4  1   a  of the Act is constitutional and that was the real ground on which it came to this Court.
